turns.text: दीदी, कृप्या मदद करो। मेरी छोटी बहन [Victim] है, करीब 16 साल की। हमारे पड़ोस वाला [Accused] उसको घर से ले जाकर मंदिर ले गया, वहाँ उसके गले में सोने जैसा धागा बाँधा, बोला अब तुम मेरी हो। बहन बहुत रो रही थी, फिर किसी तरह वापस आई। हमें बहुत डर लग रहा है, ये क्या बच्ची के साथ गलत वाला मामला माना जाएगा? पुलिस जाएँ तो क्या बोलें, हमें कुछ समझ नहीं आ रहा।

आपकी चिंता बिल्कुल सही है, यह बहुत गंभीर बात है। सबसे ज़रूरी है कि आपकी बहन अभी सुरक्षित रहे। नाबालिग लड़की को घर से ले जाना, मंदिर में शादी जैसा दिखावा करना, आम तौर पर IPC धारा 366 के दायरे में आ सकता है।
अगर रास्ते में या मंदिर में कोई छेड़छाड़ हुई हो तो IPC धारा 354, POCSO भी लग सकती है।
आप नज़दीकी थाने में जाकर FIR दर्ज कराने पर विचार करें, कोशिश करें कि महिला पुलिस के सामने बहन का बयान हो।
जरूरत हो तो 1098 पर भी बच्चे की सहायता के लिए बात कर सकते हैं।

बहन कह रही थी कि शुरू में उसने खुद जाने को हाँ बोल दी थी, बाद में डर गई। मुझे डर है पुलिस कहीं ये न बोले कि गलती हमारी है। मंदिर में बस धागा बाँधा, ज़बरदस्ती से कुछ और नहीं किया, ऐसा वो बोल रहे हैं। क्या फिर भी बच्ची वाला मामला माना जाएगा? हमारे घर वाले बदनामी से भी डर रहे हैं।

नाबालिग के मामले में क़ानून का मानना है कि 18 साल से कम उम्र की सहमति मान्य नहीं मानी जाती। ज़िम्मेदारी बड़े आदमी की मानी जाती है कि वह बच्ची को कहीं न ले जाए, न शादी जैसा करे।
इसलिए आपकी बहन ने हाँ कहा हो, तब भी पुलिस इस बात को नज़रअंदाज़ नहीं कर सकती।
अगर कोई शारीरिक छेड़छाड़ हुई हो तो यह POCSO की धारा 7, 8 के तहत भी आ सकता है।
बदनामी के डर से चुप रहना आगे और ख़तरा बढ़ा सकता है। पुलिस आपके नाम और बच्ची की पहचान गोपनीय रखती है।

अगर बाद में अदालत में बोल दें कि बहन तो तैयार थी, तो क्या वह आदमी छूट जाएगा? हमने अगर शिकायत कर दी, और बाद में मामला कमजोर हो गया, तो कहीं हमारे ही ऊपर कोई झूठी शिकायत वाला झंझट न आ जाए? सच में बहुत घबरा गए हैं, क्या करें समझ नहीं आ रहा।

अगर आप सच्चाई के आधार पर शिकायत करते हैं, तो आम तौर पर आपके ऊपर सज़ा का मामला नहीं बनता। झूठी, जानबूझकर गलत शिकायत अलग बात होती है, पर आप जो बता रहे हैं, वह गंभीर है।
अदालत उम्र, स्कूल के काग़ज़, मेडिकल, गवाह, सब देखकर फैसला करती है, नतीजे की कोई गारंटी कोई नहीं दे सकता।
मगर शिकायत करना आपका अधिकार और बच्ची की सुरक्षा के लिए ज़रूरी कदम है।
आप ज़िले की DLSA से निःशुल्क वकील की मदद भी माँग सकते हैं, वे काग़ज़ और प्रक्रिया समझा सकते हैं।

अभी तुरंत हमें क्या–क्या करना चाहिए? बहन बहुत सहमी हुई है, रात को सो भी नहीं पा रही, बार‑बार रो पड़ती है। वह पुलिस जाने से भी डर रही है कि सब उस से ही सवाल करेंगे। घर में हम कैसे बात करें, और कहाँ पर सबसे पहले संपर्क करें?

पहला कदम: बहन को सुरक्षित और भरोसेमंद माहौल में रखें, उसके साथ कोई समझदार महिला रहे, उस पर ज़ोर‑ज़बरदस्ती न करें।
धीरे‑धीरे उसे भरोसा दिलाएँ कि गलती उसकी नहीं है।
आप 1098 (बाल सहायता) या 181 (महिला सहायता) पर बात कर सकते हैं, वे मार्गदर्शन देंगे।
नज़दीकी थाने या बाल‑अनुकूल थाने में जाकर FIR दर्ज कराई जा सकती है। POCSO के तहत, धारा 24 के अनुसार, बच्ची का बयान बच्चे के अनुकूल तरीके से लिया जाना चाहिए।
अगर ज़रूरत हो तो सरकारी अस्पताल में जाँच भी कराई जा सकती है।

I am supporting a family in a POCSO case under Section 4. In the Mahila Court, the child [Victim] was examined-in-chief last year, but the defence counsel did not cross-examine that day. Much later, the accused filed a petition to recall her for cross under Section 311 CrPC, which the trial court rejected. From a procedural point of view, in child sexual abuse cases, when can a court allow recall of a child witness for cross-examination after such a delay? What is the general legal standard the High Court looks at in similar Criminal Original Petitions?

You are right to think about both fairness and the child’s well-being.

Legally:
- Section 311 CrPC allows the trial court to recall a witness if their evidence is essential to a just decision.
- This power is discretionary and must not be used to harass or re‑traumatise a child.
- Courts look at: (a) why cross was not done earlier, (b) whether recall is genuinely necessary, (c) delay, and (d) prejudice to the child versus fair trial.
- In POCSO cases, Section 33(5) POCSO and Section 309 CrPC (speedy trial) push courts to avoid repeated, avoidable appearances.

If the defence counsel earlier simply failed to cross-examine without any recorded reason, can the accused later claim violation of the right to fair trial and seek recall as a matter of right? Where the Mahila Court has refused recall, is the proper remedy a revision or a petition under Section 482 CrPC before the High Court in such POCSO matters?

Failure of counsel, by itself, does not give an automatic right to recall the child.

Courts usually ask:
- Was the lapse bona fide or a tactic?
- Is further questioning really necessary for a fair adjudication?

The right to fair trial under Article 21 is important, but balanced with child protection under POCSO.

Against refusal to recall:
- Typically, a revision under Sections 397/401 CrPC or a petition under Section 482 CrPC can be filed before the High Court.
- The High Court rarely interferes unless there is clear prejudice or arbitrariness.

From a child protection perspective, how do courts balance the risk of secondary victimisation if [Victim] is recalled, with the accused’s rights? Can the court, for example, restrict the scope of cross under Section 33(5) POCSO, use video conferencing under Section 273 CrPC, or other safeguards? We want to advise the family what protections they can ask for if recall is ultimately allowed.

Your concern about secondary victimisation is very important.

If recall is allowed, the court can:
- Apply Section 33(5) POCSO: no aggressive or humiliating questions, only what is necessary.
- Conduct in-camera proceedings.
- Use screens or video‑conferencing under Section 273 CrPC.
- Limit the duration and scope of cross‑examination.
- Allow support persons, counsellors, or assistance under the JJ Act.

You can respectfully request these safeguards through the prosecutor or your lawyer. If the family feels unsafe, they can also approach Childline 1098 or local police for protection support.

As an NGO, can we file supporting material to the trial court or High Court, such as an affidavit or short note explaining the psychological impact of repeated testimony on child sexual abuse survivors, to argue against unnecessary recall? If yes, what should we focus on so that it is helpful but does not look like we are commenting on the merits of the Section 4 POCSO charge itself?

Yes, NGOs sometimes assist courts, but it should be done carefully and through the family’s counsel or the prosecutor.

You can:
- Provide an affidavit/note focusing on general research about secondary victimisation, not this child’s credibility.
- Refer to POCSO’s objectives, Section 33(5), and JJ Act principles of best interests.
- Emphasise need to minimise repeated exposure, especially in child sexual offences (including under IPC Section 376).

Avoid commenting on guilt/innocence or specific facts. Make clear your role is child protection, not taking sides in the criminal dispute.

Regarding mandatory reporting: our NGO already reported the abuse earlier under Section 19 POCSO, and statements under Section 161 CrPC were recorded. Does a later recall application create any fresh reporting duty for us? Also, is it appropriate for us to speak with [Victim] now about how she feels about testifying again, or could that be seen as influencing her evidence?

Your earlier report under Section 19 POCSO fulfils the mandatory reporting duty; a recall application does not create a new Section 19 obligation.

About speaking with [Victim]:
- Emotional support is appropriate; avoid discussing details of the incident or suggesting what to say.
- Do not rehearse or “prepare” answers.
- Encourage her to be honest and tell the court only what she remembers.
- You can help her access counselling and legal aid through local police, Childline 1098, or the District Legal Services Authority.

Document your role as support, not evidence coaching.

I need clarity about my criminal case. I married a girl in May 2023. I was 26 and she was 17. She is an orphan and my parents arranged the marriage. Now she is pregnant. When she went for a check-up, the CDPO informed the police. An FIR is registered under POCSO, rape and child marriage law. She is staying with me willingly. Can this really be treated as rape and child sexual abuse when we are married and she agreed?

I understand this is very stressful for you and also for [Victim]. Under Indian law, any person below 18 is treated as a "child" for POCSO. Consent or marriage does not give legal protection for sexual relations with a minor. Sexual intercourse with a girl under 18 can be treated as penetrative sexual assault under POCSO and as rape under the IPC. The Prohibition of Child Marriage Act also applies because [Victim] was under 18 at marriage. You need a criminal lawyer to defend you carefully.

In our case, there was no force, no complaint from her. She has told the police she wanted to marry and wants to continue as my wife. Can the High Court quash the POCSO and rape case because it is a love marriage and she supports me? People say in some similar cases courts have closed the matter.

High Courts do have power to quash FIRs under Section 482 CrPC, but in POCSO and rape matters they are very cautious. Many courts distinguish between exploitative cases and genuine relationships, especially when ages are close and [Victim] clearly supports [Accused]. However, where there is pregnancy and serious charges like Section 6 POCSO or Section 376 IPC, courts are often reluctant to quash. Each case is fact-specific. Only your local lawyer, after reading the FIR, statements and medical papers, can advise on a quashing petition.

What kind of punishment can I face under POCSO and child marriage law if the case is not quashed? Is bail possible in such cases? I am also worried about my wife’s safety and medical care during pregnancy while this case is going on.

For penetrative sexual assault, POCSO Section 4 usually has a high minimum sentence, and Section 6 (aggravated) is even harsher. Section 376(3) IPC for rape of a girl under 16 has a long minimum sentence. Child marriage offences can add up to two years’ imprisonment and fine. Bail is possible but depends on facts, risk to [Victim], and your conduct. Ensure [Victim] gets proper medical care. She can contact Childline 1098 or the District Child Protection Unit for support. Please avoid any pressure on her about her statement.

Is our marriage itself valid or invalid in law? If the court later says it is a child marriage, what will happen to our child’s rights, like legitimacy and property, if I am convicted or if the marriage is cancelled?

Under the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, most such marriages are "voidable", not automatically void. That means [Victim], as the child spouse, can later seek to annul it within a limited time after turning 18. Until a court annuls it, the marriage is generally treated as valid. Very importantly, the law says that any child born from a child marriage is considered legitimate and is entitled to inherit from both parents, even if the marriage is later annulled by a court.
What practical steps should I take now? What documents should I collect and what should I tell my lawyer so that we can defend the case but also ensure my wife is safe and not harassed by anyone?

Gather: (1) any proof of marriage (photos, invitation, priest/temple records), (2) age documents of both of you, (3) her pregnancy and medical records, (4) any written statement or affidavit from [Victim] showing her current stand, without coaching her, (5) proof you are supporting her financially and medically. Share the entire FIR, charge sheet and these documents with a criminal lawyer. Cooperate with investigation, avoid contacting witnesses improperly, and do not pressure [Victim]. She can ask for support from the Legal Services Authority and Childline 1098.

statutes_cited: Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 - Sections 3, 4, 5, 6, 19, 24
Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006 - Sections 3, 9, 10, 11
Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015 - Section 2(14)

turns.text: I am an accused in a child safety case under the POCSO Act. The charge sheet says sexual assault and harassment, but in the child’s statement there is no clear allegation of any sexual act. Other witnesses also have not said anything about abuse. Can such a weak case be quashed under Section 482 CrPC before trial, or will the court always insist on a full trial in POCSO matters?

I understand this is very stressful for you and for everyone involved.

Under Section 482 CrPC, the High Court can quash a POCSO case if:
- The FIR and statements, even if taken as true, do not show the basic ingredients of any offence, and
- Continuing the case would be an abuse of process.

In POCSO matters, courts are cautious and usually allow trial if there is any specific allegation. But where there is no claim of sexual intent, contact, or sexually coloured act, quash is sometimes allowed.

Can you explain what exactly has to be there in the complaint for it to become sexual assault or sexual harassment under POCSO? If there is no touching or sexual words, is it still an offence, or can we argue that the basic ingredients are missing when we file for quashing?

Under the POCSO Act:

- Sexual assault (Sections 7–8): physical contact with sexual intent, without penetration. There must be some form of touching plus sexual intent.
- Sexual harassment (Sections 11–12): acts with sexual intent such as sexual comments, gestures, showing sexual material, or demanding sexual favours.

If the FIR, child’s statement, and witness statements do not show any physical contact or sexually coloured act with sexual intent, you can argue that the basic ingredients are missing and seek quashing under Section 482 CrPC.

While this is going on, I am also worried about the child and the family being exposed and judged by neighbours and media. What protections does the law give to protect the child’s identity and mental health during a POCSO case, and is there any support service they can contact?

Your concern for the child’s safety and privacy is important.

Under POCSO:
- The child’s identity cannot be published; courts usually mask names.
- Trial is generally in camera (closed court).
- Questioning of the child must be child-friendly; aggressive cross‑examination is restricted.

Under CrPC, sexual offence trials are also usually held in private. The family can:
- Call Childline 1098 for support and counselling.
- Approach the District Legal Services Authority for free legal aid and victim support services in their district.

statutes_cited: Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 - Sections 7, 8, 11, 12, 19, 24, 33

turns.text: Madam please help... meri sister [Victim] 25 saal ki hai, lekin usko mental problem hai, bachchon jaisi samajh hai. Hamare padosi [Accused] ne uske saath bura kiya lagta hai. Woh properly bol bhi nahi paati. Main bahut darr gaya hoon. Kya uske liye child waale protection law lag sakte hain ya nahi?

Mujhe samajh aa raha hai aap kitne tense honge, aap ne bahut himmat se baat ki. Law me normally “child” ka matlab hai 18 saal se kam (POCSO Act Section 2(1)(d)). Supreme Court ne Eera case me bola ki mental age ko POCSO me abhi count nahi kiya ja sakta. Iska matlab, POCSO direct apply nahi hoga, lekin IPC Sections 376, 354, 354A ke under serious case ban sakta hai. Complaint fir bhi full protection ke saath di ja sakti hai. Pehle uski safety ensure kijiye, phir police ya Childline 1098 se contact karne ka sochiye.

Police station gaye the to unhone bola POCSO nahi lagega kyunki woh 25 saal ki hai, isliye case weak hai. Yeh sunke aur dar lag gaya. Main kya bolun unko? Process kya hota hai, statement, medical, sab kaise hoga jab usko samajh bhi kam hai?

Police ka yeh kehna galat hai ki case weak ho jayega. Bas sections alag honge. Aap FIR register karwa sakte hain, usually IPC Section 376 ya 354 type offences ke tahat. Police pe duty hai FIR lena (CrPC Section 154). 
Statement: pehle police statement (CrPC Section 161), baad me Magistrate ke saamne detailed statement (CrPC Section 164). 
Medical: doctor examination hota hai, lekin uski dignity aur consent ka dhyan rakhna hota hai. Aap request kar sakte hain ki lady officer ho, aur disability-friendly tarah se baat karein.

Par woh to simple baat bhi confuse ho jaati hai, court me judge ke saamne kaise bolegi? Kya judge dhyan rakhega ki uski mental age kam hai? Mere paas uska disability certificate hai government hospital ka.

Aapka disability certificate bahut important evidence hai. Law ke hisaab se, witness ko bas itna hona chahiye ki woh sach jhoot ka basic fark samajh sake (Evidence Act Section 118). Judge aur prosecutor ko uski condition ke mutabik simple language, chhote sawal use karne chahiye. 
Supreme Court ne Eera case me yahi stress kiya ki mentally challenged adults ke saath bhi child-jaise sensitive tareeke se deal ho. Aap court se request kar sakte hain: in-camera hearing (CrPC Section 327), screen/partition, support person, ya special educator, taaki woh comfortable feel kare.
Main hi uska sab dekhbhaal karta hoon, parents bhi old hain. Kya main complainant ban sakta hoon? Koi time limit hoti hai kya aise case me report karne ki? Thoda time ho gaya hai incident ko.

Ji, aap bilkul complainant ya guardian jaisa role le sakte hain, specially jab [Victim] khud clearly complain nahi kar pa rahi. Sexual offences IPC ke under cognizable hain, police ko FIR register karna hi hota hai. Aise serious offences ke liye generally koi strict time-bar nahi hota, delay reason explain kiya ja sakta hai. 
Aap written complaint de sakte hain SHO ko, ya senior officer ko, ya speed post/email se bhi bhej sakte hain. Magistrate ke paas bhi direct application di ja sakti hai agar police cooperate na kare.
Agar POCSO nahi lagega to kya usko kam protection milega? Eera wala case aapne bola, kya future me law change ho sakta hai? Abhi ke liye hum kya extra cheezein mang sakte hain court se?

POCSO me special child-friendly procedures hote hain (Sections 3–10 offences, 19 reporting, 24 child-friendly statement), lekin Supreme Court ne Eera case me clear kiya ki abhi “child” sirf 18 se kam biological age hai. Law badalna Parliament ka kaam hai, future me ho sakta hai. 
Phir bhi, aap court se yeh cheezein maang sakte hain: 
- In-camera trial, closed courtroom (CrPC Section 327)
- Screen/partition, minimum repeated questioning (CrPC Section 273 proviso spirit)
- Interpreter/special educator under Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act
- Fast, sensitive handling, separate waiting area.

Mujhe family bhi bol rahi hai chup rehne ko, par main guilty feel kar raha hoon. Free lawyer ya NGO kaise milega jo disability aur sexual violence dono samjhe? Phone pe kaunse number pe help mil sakti hai?

Aap akela nahi hain, aap jo kar rahe hain woh [Victim] ki safety ke liye bahut zaroori hai. Kuch options:
- Childline 1098: complain kar sakte hain, guidance milega, chahe woh 18 se upar ho, phir bhi connect kara sakte hain.
- Women/violence helpline (kai states me 181 ya 1091) se counselling aur referral.
- District Legal Services Authority (DLSA): free legal aid lawyer; online “DLSA + [aapka district]” search karein.
- Local One Stop Centre / women & child NGO: woh police, medical, court sab me accompany kar sakte hain.
Aap pehle apni aur [Victim] ki immediate safety ensure kijiye.

statutes_cited: Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016

turns.text: Sir please help, main bahut darr gaya hoon. Mere 10 saal ke bete ke saath ek aadmi ne bahut galat kaam kiya, doctor ne bola sexual assault jaisa lagta hai. Police ne complaint likh li hai, par mujhe samajh nahi aa raha aage kya hoga, us aadmi ko kitni saza ho sakti hai? Kya mera beta baar‑baar police aur court ke saamne bolna padega? Woh already bahut dara hua hai, raat ko sone se bhi dar raha hai.

Main aapki situation samajh sakta hoon, yeh bahut traumatic hai. Aapke beta ki age ke hisaab se yeh case POCSO Act ke under aata hai, especially agar penetrative sexual assault hua ho toh Sections 3–6 lag sakte hain, jisme 10 saal se life imprisonment tak punishment ho sakti hai. Saath me IPC 323 ya 377 bhi apply ho sakte hain. Aapko turant FIR register karni chahiye, medical reports preserve rakhein. Childline 1098, ya kisi free legal aid lawyer/NGO se bhi support le sakte hain.

Thank you sir… par mujhe sabse zyada tension yeh hai ki mera beta ko kitni baar statement dena padega? Police ne bola phir court me bhi bolna hoga, woh sun ke woh aur ghabra gaya. Kya law me aisa kuch hai ki bachche ko kam se kam baar bolna pade? Kya lady police ya counsellor ke saamne uska bayan ho sakta hai? Aur kya hum log uske saath court room me reh sakte hain?

Aksar child ka statement police ek hi baar friendly tareeke se record karti hai, POCSO Section 24 ke hisaab se. Phir Magistrate ke samne 164 CrPC statement hota hai. Court mein bhi Special POCSO Court hoti hai, in‑camera hearing, public allowed nahi, parents/guardian reh sakte hain. Judge normally bachche ko repeat narration se bachane ki koshish karta hai. Aap request kar sakte hain ki woman IO ho, female support person ya counsellor ho. Zaroorat ho toh Legal Services Authority se free lawyer maang sakte hain.

भाई साहब, कृपया मदद करो। मेरी 11 साल की बेटी [Victim] है, उसके चाचा [Accused] ने गलत हरकत की थी, हमने पुलिस में FIR कराई, उन्होंने POCSO लगा दिया। अब वो लोग कह रहे हैं कि जबलपुर वाले उच्च न्यायालय से कोई आदेश आ जाएगा तो मामला ही खत्म हो जाएगा और हम कुछ नहीं कर पाएंगे। मुझे बहुत डर लग रहा है, बेटी रोज रोती है। मुझे समझ नहीं आ रहा ये उच्च न्यायालय वाला मामला क्या होता है, क्या सच में FIR खत्म हो सकती है?

आप जो बता रही हैं, वह बहुत दर्दनाक है, मैं आपकी चिंता समझता हूँ। आपकी बेटी की सुरक्षा सबसे जरूरी है। यदि आपने FIR दर्ज कराई है और मामला POCSO तथा IPC की धाराओं के तहत चल रहा है, तो केवल आरोपी के कह देने से मामला खत्म नहीं होता। उच्च न्यायालय सबूत, बयान और पूरे प्रकरण को देखकर FIR रद्द करने पर विचार करता है। बिना आपकी बात सुने अदालत फैसला नहीं करती। आप सरकारी वकील से मिलकर आदेश की प्रति लेकर ठीक से समझ लें, और जरूरत हो तो DLSA से नि:शुल्क मदद लें।

अगर बाद में उच्च न्यायालय से उनको जमानत या कुछ राहत मिल गई तो हमारी हालत क्या होगी। वो लोग तो मोहल्ले में ही रहते हैं, रोज रास्ता रोकेंगे, बदनाम करेंगे। मेरी बेटी स्कूल भी नहीं जाना चाहती, उसे हर समय डर लगता है। क्या मैं कहीं से सुरक्षा मांग सकती हूँ, या मामला अपने जिले से दूसरी जगह भेजने की गुहार कर सकती हूँ, ताकि वो लोग दबाव न बना सकें? मुझे कदम‑कदम पर क्या करना चाहिए, थोड़ा साफ‑साफ बता दीजिए।

यदि आरोपी को जमानत मिल भी जाए, तब भी कानून आपकी बेटी की सुरक्षा को प्राथमिकता देता है। आप नजदीकी थाने में लिखित आवेदन देकर बता सकती हैं कि आरोपी से डर है और आप सुरक्षा चाहती हैं; पुलिस भविष्य में किसी घटना को रोकने के लिए CrPC की धाराओं के तहत कदम उठा सकती है। यदि दबाव या धमकी हो तो तुरंत सूचना दें, यह भी अलग अपराध है। आप 1098 या महिला हेल्पलाइन 181 पर बात कर सकती हैं, और DLSA से लिखित रूप में सुरक्षा और जरूरत हो तो घर बदलने जैसी सहायता मांग सकती हैं।

I am supporting [Complainant] in a cruelty and dowry case (Sections 498A, 323, 504, 506 IPC and Section 4 Dowry Prohibition Act). The accused have filed a petition under Section 482 CrPC to quash the proceedings. What factors will the High Court usually look at for quashing in such matrimonial cases, and does this affect her safety meanwhile? Also, [Complainant]'s minor niece has disclosed inappropriate touching by [Accused 4]. Do we now have a duty of mandatory reporting under Section 19 POCSO, and how does Section 24 apply here?

The High Court usually examines whether: (a) the FIR and charge-sheet disclose a prima facie offence, (b) the case is malicious or an abuse of process, and (c) in matrimonial disputes, whether any settlement is genuine and voluntary. Until there is a stay, the trial and protection orders can continue.

Regarding the minor niece, anyone with knowledge of sexual offences against a child has a duty to report under Section 19 POCSO. Section 24 requires child-friendly procedures: minimal questioning, privacy, and no harassment. You may approach the police, Childline 1098, and the Child Welfare Committee.

If there are compromise talks in the 498A/dowry case, can the family include the POCSO issue in the same settlement memorandum, for example agreeing not to pursue the POCSO allegations? Would that affect our Section 19 POCSO duty or any future quashing petition of a POCSO FIR under Section 482? Also, how can we practically protect the child from pressure to retract during mediation or Lok Adalat-type discussions?

Sexual offences under POCSO are non-compoundable. A settlement cannot remove the Section 19 duty or legally cancel a POCSO case; the child’s rights cannot be bargained away. High Courts are very cautious about quashing POCSO FIRs on compromise.

For protection: ask the court that the child not attend joint mediation sessions; request separate waiting areas and a support person (per POCSO Rules); insist on no direct interaction with [Accused]; and inform the mediator and court in writing if there is any pressure or intimidation. You may also alert the Child Welfare Committee.

The minor has not yet given a detailed statement. Should we request an early statement before the Magistrate under Section 164 CrPC, or wait until she has more counselling support? How does this balance with child-friendly requirements under POCSO and the risk of secondary trauma? Is it legally problematic if she first discloses fully to a counsellor and only later to the police or Magistrate?

You can request an early Section 164 CrPC statement so her memory is recorded while still fresh, but it should be done in a child-friendly manner: presence of a trusted person, minimal waiting, and no aggressive questioning, as required under POCSO and its Rules. Parallel counselling is allowed and often helpful; it is not legally wrong if she first speaks to a counsellor. The counsellor may later be a witness. Ask the Investigating Officer to avoid repeated interviews and to coordinate with counsellors to reduce trauma.

Sir please help… maine ek news jaisa case padha tha Karnataka High Court ka, child care home mein abuse wala… bola gaya evidence nahi tha isliye aadmi choot gaya. Main bohot dar gaya hoon. Mere ek cousin [Victim] bhi ek Child Care Institution mein thi, usne bhi kuch aisa hint kiya tha. Agar proof na ho toh kya kuch nahi ho sakta?

Mujhe samajh aa raha hai aap kitne tension mein hain, aisa sunke kisi ko bhi dar lagega.

Law ke hisaab se child ka statement khud ek important evidence hota hai. POCSO Act ke under sexual assault (jaise Section 3–7) aur IPC (jaise Section 354, 376) ke cases mein court sirf child ki believable baat par bhi convict kar sakti hai. Karnataka wale case mein court ne kaha ki har case alag hota hai; evidence ki kami ho toh hi acquittal hota hai, automatic nahi. Aap cousin ki safety pehle ensure karein.

Par sir, wahan koi eyewitness nahi hoga, CCTV bhi shayad nahi. [Victim] bohot dar rahi hai, clearly bol nahi pa rahi. Aise mein police ya court maanenge? Agar do saal baad complaint karein toh bolenge late kyun kiya… mujhe samajh nahi aa raha kya karun.

Child sexual abuse cases mein aksar eyewitness nahi hote, phir bhi case banta hai. Law ke hisaab se corroboration zaroori condition nahi hai; agar child ka statement consistent, natural aur pressure-free lage toh court use accept kar sakti hai.

Delay bhi samajh ke saath dekha jata hai, kyunki bachche ko dar, shame, ya threat ho sakta hai. POCSO Section 19 reporting ke baare mein hai, aur Section 24 child-friendly recording ke liye. Aap soch sakte hain: local police station, SP office, ya Childline 1098 pe baat karne ka.

Agar hum ab report karna chahein toh exact process kya hoga? Pehle police, ya Childline, ya jo CCI wale log hain unko? Mujhe dar hai CCI ke log hi cover up na kar dein, kyunki shayad wahi staff involved ho sakta hai.

Agar CCI staff par doubt ho, toh unse bypass karke directly complaint karna safer ho sakta hai.

Possible steps:
1) Turant Childline 1098 par call – woh guidance aur rescue coordinate kar sakte hain.
2) Nearest police station / women police station mein jaake FIR register karwana – POCSO + IPC sections ke under.
3) District Child Protection Unit ya Child Welfare Committee ko inform karna – JJ Act ke under woh CCI ko monitor karte hain.
4) [Victim] ka statement child-friendly tareeke se magistrate ke samne record ho sakta hai.

Agar FIR ho jaye aur case court mein jaaye, phir bhi agar woh Karnataka wala jaisa result aa gaya, accused acquit ho gaya, toh phir [Victim] ka kya? Log to bolenge jhooth bola. Uski life, uska future kaun sambhalega?

Court se acquittal ka matlab yeh nahi hota ki child jhooth bol raha tha, sirf itna ki ‘beyond reasonable doubt’ proof nahi mila. Judge ko accused aur victim dono ke rights balance karne hote hain.

Aise case mein:
- State ya complainant appeal file kar sakte hain higher court mein.
- [Victim] ko counseling, psychological support mil sakta hai (District Legal Services Authority / NGOs se).
- Victim Compensation Scheme ke through financial help mil sakti hai; POCSO Section 33(8) bhi compensation ka framework deta hai.
Ek last baat… agar hum report karein toh kya [Victim] ka naam sab jagah aa jayega? School, friends, media… usko aur trauma ho jayega. Law mein koi protection hai kya identity ke liye?

Ji haan, law specifically identity protect karta hai. POCSO aur IPC ke under:

- Case in-camera hota hai, public ko court se bahar rakha ja sakta hai.
- Media ko victim ka naam, photo, address publish karna mana hai (POCSO Section 23 type protection).
- Court records sealed tareeke se rakhe ja sakte hain.

Aap lawyer se request kar sakte hain ki judge se closed court, screen, ya video-conference ke through evidence lene ki permission maange. School/CCI se safe transfer aur counseling bhi arrange ho sakti hai.

statutes_cited: Juvenile Justice (JJ) Act – Child Care Institution and Child Welfare Committee provisions
Victim Compensation Scheme (state-specific, read with POCSO)

turns.text: We are supporting a family where [Minor] was sexually assaulted by a maintenance worker inside a gated residential complex. The facility was earlier run by a property management company and then handed over to the RWA, similar to the electrocution case where control was disputed. In a POCSO matter like this, how do courts usually look at negligence and duty of care of (a) the old management company and (b) the present RWA, when the assault occurs after a formal handover?

I am sorry your team is dealing with this. In such situations, courts usually separate: 

1) Criminal liability for sexual offences (POCSO, IPC) – this is mainly on the individual offender, and sometimes on those who failed to report.
2) Negligence / institutional liability – who had effective control when the assault occurred.

If there was a clear, documented handover (like in the electrocution case), primary duty of care is usually on the entity in control at the time (often the RWA), but prior negligence in hiring or screening can still be examined.

On mandatory reporting: if the Vice President of the earlier management company learns about the POCSO incident now, but had already handed over control months before, does Section 19 POCSO still create a duty on him personally to report? Also, could Section 21 POCSO or any vicarious liability apply to the management company itself in these circumstances?

Under Section 19 POCSO, the duty to report applies to “any person” who has knowledge, irrespective of present control of the premises. So the former Vice President should still report to police/Childline 1098.

Section 21 POCSO penalises failure to report; it can apply to individuals in charge of institutions. Company liability is possible if non-reporting is linked to company policy or directions, but this is fact-specific and assessed by the court. A local lawyer should review all documents.

For the child’s testimony and protection, we want to ensure the process is safe. Could you outline the usual steps: FIR registration, statement under CrPC, and how POCSO Section 24 about child-friendly procedures works in practice? Also, can we parallelly move for compensation or interim relief while the criminal case is ongoing?

Typical steps are:

1) FIR under POCSO/IPC (usually Section 154 CrPC).
2) Statement of [Minor] preferably by a woman officer in a safe place (Section 24 POCSO).
3) Magistrate’s statement under Section 164 CrPC, in-camera, child-friendly.
4) Medical and psychosocial support.

For compensation, you may:
- Seek victim compensation under the Victim Compensation Scheme.
- Request interim compensation through the Special POCSO Court.

Your NGO can accompany the family and coordinate with the Special Public Prosecutor.

Coming back to negligence, in building a civil or criminal negligence argument against an institution, what kinds of documents or evidence best show who actually had operational control at the time of the offence? We want to avoid unfairly targeting someone who, like in the electrocution case, had clearly divested control.

Evidence of control can include:

- Registered handover agreements between the builder/management firm and the RWA.
- Minutes of meetings showing transfer of maintenance and staffing powers.
- Bank records showing who paid staff salaries at the time.
- Security/maintenance contracts with agencies.
- Access control logs and SOPs issued by the controlling entity.
- Insurance policies naming the “insured” for common areas.

Courts tend to focus on who could realistically set and enforce safety rules when the offence occurred.

For prevention and to show due diligence in future cases, what written policies and safeguards should an RWA or facility manager adopt regarding child safety—especially when outsiders like maintenance staff or coaches access common areas? Would courts generally look positively at a documented child protection policy if a POCSO incident still occurs?

Helpful measures include:

- A written Child Protection Policy, adopted by resolution.
- Mandatory background checks and ID verification for all staff/vendors.
- Clear access rules for outsiders in children’s areas.
- CCTV in common spaces (not in private areas), with logs.
- Training for staff on POCSO and Section 19 reporting.
- Designated Child Protection Officer for the complex.

Courts usually view genuine, implemented safeguards positively, though they do not erase liability if there is actual negligence. These measures mainly protect children and reduce risk.

Mera 16 saal ka bhatija [Minor] ek murder case (302, 323, 504, 506, 109, 120B, 34 IPC) me naam aa gaya hai. JJB Hardoi ne bail reject ki, phir Special Judge POCSO (Appeal 43/2024) ne bhi mana kar diya. Ab hum High Court me revision soch rahe hain. Kya Section 102 Juvenile Justice Act ke under revision possible hai? Aur itne serious offence me bhi juvenile ko bail ka kuch special protection milta hai kya?

Aapke bhatije ki situation bahut stressful hogi, yeh samajh sakta hoon. Haan, Juvenile Justice Act Section 102 ke through High Court me criminal revision file kiya ja sakta hai, JJB aur appellate court ke orders challenge karne ke liye. Bail ke liye special rule Section 12 JJ Act me hai: child ko bail “rule” hai, denial sirf tab jab court ko lage ki (1) criminal association ka risk, (2) moral/physical/psychological danger, ya (3) justice ke interest me nahi. Sirf offence ki gravity basis nahi ban sakti. Detention observation home me hi hona chahiye, jail me nahi.

Appeal jisne decide ki woh Special Judge POCSO hai, lekin is case me sexual allegation kuch nahi hai. Kya POCSO Court hone se koi extra presumption lagta hai? Aur hum revision me yeh bol sakte hain ki bail reject order me Section 12 ke grounds properly discuss nahi kiye gaye? High Court se interim relief ya stay mil sakta hai kya?

Special Judge POCSO sirf ek designated court hai; agar FIR me POCSO offence hi nahi hai, to POCSO ke presumptions (Sections 29–30) normally apply nahi hote. Aap revision me yeh strong ground le sakte hain ki JJB/appeal court ne Section 12 JJ Act ke teen grounds ka proper analysis nahi kiya, sirf “offence serious hai” likh diya. High Court se interim bail ya proceedings ka stay manga ja sakta hai, lekin yeh purely judicial discretion hai, guarantee nahi. Local criminal lawyer se milke detailed revision draft karwana zaroori hoga.

Agar maan lo isi type ka case hota lekin [Victim] ke saath sexual abuse ka allegation bhi hota, to process kaise different hota? FIR, POCSO sections, child-friendly procedure, yeh sab kaise chalega? 16 saal ki victim ko statement, counselling, protection ke liye kaun help karega? Kya JJ Act usko ‘child in need of care and protection’ maan kar kuch extra support deta hai?

Agar sexual abuse allegation ho, to normally FIR POCSO + relevant IPC Sections ke under register hoti hai. POCSO Section 19 ke hisaab se reporting mandatory hai; police ko child-friendly tareeke se kaam karna hota hai, aur Section 24 ke mutabik statement non‑threatening environment me record hota hai. Trial Special Court (Section 28 POCSO) me hota hai. Victim ko support person, counsellor, medical aid aur compensation DLSA/Court ke through mil sakta hai. JJ Act ke under aisi victim ko “child in need of care and protection” maana ja sakta hai, jisse CWC shelter, counselling, safety plan arrange kar sakta hai. Aap Childline 1098 ya Child Welfare Police Officer se bhi contact kar sakte hain.

turns.text: Sir please help… meri beti school me ek [Teacher] ke sath kuch galat hua tha… woh touch karta tha ajeeb tareeke se… hum log darr gaye the isliye pehle kisi ko nahi bataya. Ab kaafi time ho gaya hai, ab principal bol rahe hain proof nahi hai, case weak ho jayega. Mujhe samajh nahi aa raha kya karun… main bahut dara hua hoon.

Mujhe afsos hai ki [Victim] ke saath aisa hua, aapka dar bilkul samajh aa raha hai. Pehle safety important hai: ensure kijiye ki [Teacher] se door rakha jaye. Abhi bhi aap formal complaint kar sakte hain. Is type ka matter POCSO Act ke under aata hai, jaise Section 7–8 (sexual assault) ya Section 9–10 (aggravated). Aap nearest police station ya women police station me jaakar FIR de sakte hain, aur Childline 1098 par bhi call kar sakte hain.

Par sir, sab bol rahe hain itna late complaint se court me faayda nahi hoga, judge bol dega jhooth hai. Maine suna kai cases me aadmi chhoot jata hai kyunki bacha ya family late bolte hain, ya baad me ghabra ke kuch ulta seedha bol dete hain. Agar hum ab complaint karein to delay se problem hogi kya?

Delay se case automatically kharab nahi ho jata, par court reason dekhta hai. Child sexual abuse me dar, shame, family pressure ki wajah se delay common hai, aur courts ne accept bhi kiya hai. Lekin prosecution ko phir bhi guilt "beyond reasonable doubt" prove karna hota hai. Isliye zaroori hai: 1) [Victim] ka clear, consistent statement (police aur magistrate ke samne – POCSO Section 24), 2) jo witnesses sach jante hain woh support karein, 3) medical/other supporting evidence ho to helpful hoga.

Agar kal ko court me [Teacher] ko chhod diya, jaise log news me bolte hain, to phir meri beti ka kya? School wale bhi chup rehna chahte hain. Kya school ya government se koi protection mil sakti hai? Aur kya aise case me upar wali court me ja sakte hain?

Agar trial court se acquittal ho jaye, normally State government appeal file kar sakti hai higher court me. Aap apne lawyer se discuss karke appeal ya revision ka option dekh sakte hain. Parallel me: 1) School management ko written complaint dijiye, internal inquiry maang sakte hain, 2) District Child Protection Unit ya Child Welfare Committee (CWC) ke paas jaa sakte hain (JJ Act ke under), 3) [Victim] ke liye free counselling aur support services demand kar sakte hain.

Abhi turant mujhe practical kya steps lene chahiye? Main lawyer afford mushkil se kar paunga, bachchi bhi bahut dar rahi hai, police se bhi ghabra rahi hai. Kya woh directly judge ko bol sakti hai? Aur kya mujhe school ke khilaf bhi kuch karna chahiye ki unhone pehle serious nahi liya?

Practical steps: 1) Childline 1098 par call kijiye – free hai, counsellor aur legal support arrange kar sakte hain. 2) Nearest police station me written complaint dijiye; POCSO Section 19 ke hisaab se police ko mandatory action lena hota hai. 3) [Victim] ka statement child‑friendly tareeke se record hona chahiye (POCSO Section 24); judge ke samne baad me evidence ke time aayega. 4) School ke khilaf written complaint DEO/education department ko bhi de sakte hain.

मेरी भांजी लगभग 17 साल की है। मोहल्ले का एक आदमी उसका रोज़ पीछा करता है, रास्ता रोकता है और गंदी बातें कहता है। एक दिन उसने हाथ पकड़ने की भी कोशिश की। हमने थाना अमन विहार में शिकायत दी, पुलिस ने कहा कि पीछा करने वाली धारा और बाल सुरक्षा कानून लगेंगे, शायद POCSO भी। क्या यह मामला POCSO और IPC दोनों में आएगा? और अभी हमें क्या‑क्या कदम उठाने चाहिए ताकि बच्ची सुरक्षित रहे?

आपने बहुत सही किया कि तुरंत शिकायत दी, आपकी भांजी की सुरक्षा सबसे ज़रूरी है।
आपके बताए अनुसार यह अपराध सामान्यतः धारा 354D IPC (पीछा करना) और POCSO की धारा 11, 12 (यौन उत्पीड़क हरकत) के अन्तर्गत आ सकता है, क्योंकि बच्ची 18 वर्ष से कम है।
कदम:
1. लिखित शिकायत की प्रति अपने पास रखें।
2. बच्ची का बयान महिला अधिकारी के सामने दिलवाएँ।
3. यदि आरोपी फिर से परेशान करे तो तुरंत 112 पर सूचित करें।
4. आवश्यकता हो तो DLSA से निःशुल्क वकील और परामर्श लें।

पुलिस ने FIR दर्ज कर ली है, आरोपी अभी ज़मानत पर बाहर है और वही रास्ता पकड़ कर चलता है, जिससे बच्ची रोज़ डरकर स्कूल जाती है। क्या हम अदालत से यह कहलवा सकते हैं कि वह स्कूल और घर के आसपास न आए? और गवाही के समय बच्ची पर दबाव या उससे उलटे‑सीधे सवाल न हों, इसके लिए POCSO में क्या सुरक्षा है?

आप आवेदन देकर अदालत से अनुरोध कर सकते हैं कि आरोपी को घर, स्कूल और बच्ची से निश्चित दूरी बनाए रखने की शर्त लगाई जाए; यदि वह शर्त तोड़े तो अभियोजन पक्ष पुलिस के माध्यम से अदालत को बता सकता है।
POCSO में प्रावधान है कि:
1. गवाही आम जनता से अलग, बाल‑अनुकूल माहौल में हो सकती है।
2. अनुचित, डराने वाले प्रश्नों पर आपके वकील को आपत्ति करने का अधिकार है।
3. बच्ची का बयान धारा 164 CrPC के तहत मजिस्ट्रेट के सामने सुरक्षित ढंग से दर्ज हो सकता है।

I was reading a recent Gujarat High Court order where a 17 years 7 months girl left home with the accused in a romantic relationship. The Court treated it as kidnapping and rape under IPC and POCSO, and considered that consent was legally irrelevant while deciding regular bail under Section 439 CrPC. In such near‑18 cases, does the minor’s statement under Section 164 CrPC about going willingly have any real impact, or do courts usually ignore it entirely because of POCSO’s strict age limit?

You are right that under POCSO, anyone below 18 is legally a child, so “consent” does not make the sexual act lawful. However, the statement under Section 164 CrPC is still important. Courts may use it to understand: whether force or deception was used, the nature of the relationship, and risk of re‑victimisation. For bail under Section 439 CrPC, judges can consider her version, age close to 18, and absence of violence, but cannot treat it as legal consent or erase the offence.

In a similar romantic‑elopement situation, if the family files an FIR under Sections 363, 366, 376 IPC and POCSO, what is our duty as an NGO under Section 19 POCSO? We often see the girl insisting she went voluntarily and fears action against the boy. Are we still bound to report, and is there any way to place her perspective on record so that the law is not misused against consensual‑looking adolescent relationships?

Section 19 POCSO makes reporting mandatory for anyone who has knowledge of a sexual offence against a child. So, as an NGO, you must report or support the existing FIR; you cannot suppress information because the girl calls it consensual. However, you can: help her give a clear, voluntary statement under Sections 161/164 CrPC; inform the police and Child Welfare Committee about the romantic context; request child‑friendly procedures under Section 24 POCSO; and link her to Childline 1098 and legal aid so her voice is heard.

Once such an FIR is registered, can the accused realistically seek regular bail under Section 439 CrPC by relying on (a) her age being close to 18, and (b) her consistent statements that she went with him voluntarily? What kind of material usually helps the defence in a bail hearing, and parallelly, what support measures should we ensure for the [Victim] during investigation and trial in these romantic‑but‑criminalised cases?

The accused can apply for regular bail under Section 439 CrPC, and courts often consider near‑majority, prior relationship, lack of threats, and the [Victim]’s consistent statements. Still, POCSO and Section 376 IPC are serious, so bail is never assured. Defence usually relies on call records, messages, travel details, and absence of injuries or force. For the [Victim], try to ensure: support person under POCSO Rules, counselling, in‑camera trial, minimal repeated questioning, legal aid, and Child Welfare Committee involvement where needed.

मैं 19 साल का हूँ। मेरे खिलाफ शिकायत हुई है कि मैंने एक नाबालिग लड़की के साथ संबंध बनाया, उसके माता‑पिता ने पुलिस में शिकायत दी है और अब POCSO लगाने की बात हो रही है। मुझे समझ नहीं आ रहा कि आगे क्या होगा। क्या ऐसे मामले में जमानत मिल सकती है? और कौन‑कौन से कानून लग सकते हैं?

आपकी स्थिति काफ़ी तनावपूर्ण होगी, यह समझ में आता है। नाबालिग के साथ यौन संबंध के आरोप आम तौर पर POCSO की गंभीर धाराओं के तहत आते हैं, और साथ में IPC की धाराएँ, जैसे 376 या 354 वग़ैरह भी लग सकती हैं, यह आरोपों पर निर्भर है।

जमानत पूरी तरह न्यायालय के विवेक पर होती है। सामान्यतः पहले निचली अदालत, फिर ज़रूरत हो तो ऊपरी अदालत में जमानत के लिए आवेदन किया जाता है। अभी आप किसी सक्षम आपराधिक वकील से तुरंत संपर्क करें, और पुलिस जाँच में सहयोग दें।

पुलिस ने मुझे नोटिस भेजा है, गिरफ़्तारी भी हो सकती है बोल रहे हैं। अगर मुझे पकड़ लिया गया तो कितने दिन तक जेल में रख सकते हैं? जमानत के लिए कौन‑सी अदालत में आवेदन करना होगा, और क्या यह साधारण जमानती मामला माना जाएगा या नहीं?

POCSO और बलात्कार जैसे आरोप आम तौर पर साधारण जमानती नहीं माने जाते। पुलिस आपको बिना मजिस्ट्रेट के सामने पेश किए आमतौर पर चौबीस घंटे से ज़्यादा नहीं रख सकती। उसके बाद न्यायिक हिरासत या ज़मानत पर निर्णय होता है।

ऐसे मामलों में प्रायः पहले सत्र न्यायालय में जमानत याचिका दायर की जाती है, और अगर वहाँ से न मिले तो बाद में उच्च न्यायालय जा सकते हैं, CrPC की धारा 437, 439 के तहत। आप जितनी जल्दी हो सके किसी अनुभवी आपराधिक वकील को सारे काग़ज़ात दिखाएँ।
मान लीजिए लड़की बाद में अदालत में कह दे कि उसने अपने घर वालों के दबाव में शिकायत की थी, तो क्या POCSO के आरोप अपने‑आप हट जाएँगे? क्या पीड़िता और उसके परिवार से समझौता करके मामला खत्म किया जा सकता है?

POCSO के मामलों में अपराध को राज्य बनाम अभियुक्त माना जाता है, केवल परिवारों के बीच विवाद नहीं, इसलिए सामान्य समझौता करके मामला अपने‑आप खत्म नहीं होता। अदालत पूरे साक्ष्य, बयान और जाँच रिपोर्ट देखती है।

यदि पीड़िता अपना बयान बदलती है, तो भी न्यायालय यह देखेगा कि वह स्वेच्छा से बोल रही है या दबाव में नहीं। किसी भी तरह की धमकी या दबाव क़ाननन अपराध है। बेहतर है कि आप क़ानूनी प्रक्रिया का सम्मान करें, सच‑सच अपने वकील को बताएँ और न्यायालय में वही रखें।

Please help me. My husband is keeping my 11 year old daughter with him. My girl told me he touched her in bad way. I am very scared. He is not allowing me to meet her now. I want my child back and I want case on him. I dont understand law. What can I do?

I am very sorry you and your daughter are going through this. Your and your child’s safety come first.

You may:
1. Go to the nearest police station and give a written complaint. This can be treated as a case under the POCSO Act and IPC.
2. Call Childline 1098 and report the abuse.
3. File a case in Family Court/High Court for custody of your daughter.
4. Ask for free legal aid from the State Legal Services Authority.

Do you feel safe where you are right now?

I am safe but my daughter is not. Police already know some things but they are slow, they say it is family matter. My husband has money and contacts. I am worried they will not believe me. Can court still help me get my child? I dont have big proof, only what my child told me.

What your daughter told you is important. In child sexual abuse cases, the child’s statement is strong evidence.

You may:
- Give a detailed written complaint again, mentioning that it is sexual abuse of a minor. This may fall under POCSO sections on sexual assault and IPC offences like outraging modesty or rape.
- Police are required to register an FIR in such cases (POCSO reporting duty).
- You can move the High Court/Family Court for custody, telling the court about the abuse and slow police action.
- Legal aid lawyers can help you file these quickly.

My daughter is very scared of her father. If police or judge ask her, she may start crying. Will she have to talk in front of him? I don’t want her to get more trauma. How will they take her statement?

The law tries to protect children during this process.

Under the POCSO Act:
- The child’s statement should be taken in a child‑friendly way, preferably by a woman officer, often at a place comfortable for the child.
- The child should not face the accused directly in court; proceedings are generally in camera (closed court).
- The judge can allow screens, video link, or separate waiting areas.
- A support person or counsellor can be provided.

You can clearly tell police and the court that your daughter is afraid and needs these protections.
I also want full custody. Right now she is with him. Earlier he had also filed some case for custody. If I file now saying he abused her, will court listen to me? Can they stop him from seeing her?

Custody decisions are based on the “best interests of the child,” under laws like the Guardians and Wards Act.

Allegations of sexual abuse are very serious. If the court finds risk to the child, it can:
- Give you interim custody,
- Restrict or stop the father’s access, or
- Allow only supervised visitation.

You will need to:
- Tell the court clearly about the abuse and pending criminal complaint,
- Request urgent/interim custody.

The court will look at all facts; no one can promise the result, but these facts are highly relevant.
I feel very lost. Please tell me step by step what I should do today and tomorrow. I am alone, don’t have much money. How to start for both police case and custody?

Step‑by‑step, you may consider:

Today:
1. Ensure your own safety.
2. Call Childline 1098 and report everything.
3. Go to the nearest police station (or women’s police station) with any messages, medical papers, or prior complaints and give a written complaint asking for FIR under POCSO.

Next:
4. Approach the District Legal Services Authority or High Court Legal Services Committee for a free lawyer.
5. With that lawyer, file for:
   - Custody/interim custody in Family/High Court,
   - Directions to police to investigate quickly.
